titleInfo.title: Oral history interview with Angelo Anderson and Angela Anderson Jones, 1986 October 21

mods.identifier: OHP86Anderson1aclip1.mp3; OHP86Anderson1aclip2.mp3; OHP86Anderson1aclip3.mp3; OHP86Anderson1aclip4.mp3; OHP86Anderson1bclip1.mp3; OHP86Anderson1bclip2.mp3; OHP86Anderson2clip1.mp3; OHP86Anderson2clip2.mp3; OHP86Anderson_transcript.pdf

physicalDescription.note: Excerpted from: OHP86Anderson audio cassette recording converted to digital format in 2006.

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections Division of the Nashville Public Library, 615 Church Street, Nashville, Tennessee, 37219

mods.abstract: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Angelo Anderson and his daughter Angela Anderson Jones, conducted on 21 Oct. 1986 by John Egerton as part of the Homecoming '86 Oral History Project. Anderson and Jones discuss Anderson's immigration to the United States from Greece in 1901 and his experiences upon arrival in the U.S.; Anderson's conscription into the Greek army while on a visit back home in 1912; Anderson's buying his uncle's shoeshine business in 1905; other Greek families in Nashville; Anderson's witnessing the Cooper-Carmack shooting in 1908; Anderson's business experiences in Nashville, including operating Candyland; Greek traditions that continued in the United States, including "fixed" marriages and membership in the Greek Orthodox Church; and Anderson's wine making during Prohibition. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.
